1115676099030192131.text: Which leads to the phenomenon, also observed in other transportation scenarios, that we are far more tolerant of humans killing other humans, vs machines. Because we can't see who would be on the track-not-taken of this particular trolley problem.

1115668534074466305.text: But when confronted with news about autonomous vehicle accidents, our mental calculus is a different one. We don't ask ourselves if the vehicle had managed to save lives in the past, but if the pedestrian could still be alive if it weren't for the maneuver enacted by a machine.

1115665625546993664.text: The answer to this question is somewhat schizophrenic. When asked in the abstract, we'd certainly welcome a project that proposes to save 900,000 lives per year.

1115662481605763073.text: With the somewhat belatedly emerging recognition that zero accident autonomous driving is further away than expected, a new question arises: namely whether we would be willing to introduce a system that is capable of reducing fatalities by, say, 90%, to 100,000 deaths globally.

1115661813486583808.text: Currently vehicular traffic causes about 1 million fatalities er year. A social cost we grudgingly bear (and overall expenditure on zero accident research projects lets us create a monetary estimate for the social value of a human life).

1115660860159143937.text: Modern research into autonomous vehicles has its roots in the overall goal of reducing vehicle accidents in the face of increasing vehicle usage and urbanization, with the stated long-term goal of "zero accidents".

1115659826514800650.text: But the actual dilemma is much older, much more contracted, and it involves a public choice under unobservable counterfactuals.

1115659825076146182.text: The trolley problem is often invoked as a metaphor for the ethical dilemma autonomous vehicle designers face. Should I activate a driving maneuver to avoid a head-on collision with multiple fatalities even if that maneuver might kill an uninvolved bystander?

1107049248686780417.text: But it is also much easier to build longitudinal models when there is only a single actor for which things have to be optimized.

1107048678450184192.text: Another notable distinction is the preference for dynamic/longitudinal (IE) vs comparative-static (IO) analytical methods. This might be due to the fact that the firm is seen as an ongoing concern while the market facilitates spot transactions.

1107047264621604864.text: Working on adjacent subjects (firms and markets) and using a similar toolset surprisingly doesn't mean there is a steady flow of exchange between the fields, as the glacial speed of the knowledge spillover of things like machine learning (IE»IO) or game theory (IO»IE) shows.

1107045358541127681.text:
IO follows economics in the trend towards applying the scientific method, meaning econometrics, and in particular OLS regression analysis. 

A big reason for that is that traditionally, economists worked for public organizations, where the burden of proof was inordinately higher.

1107045353851928577.text: The biggest difference is in the tools used for empirical testing. IE is in this regard very much in the engineering tradition of building things, creating test data, and stress testing the system until failure points are known and fixed.

1107043737421705216.text:
It would be a bit limiting to restrict IE to "decision science under uncertainty", but decision theory and graph theory (incl networks) are important tools.

The most important tool of modern IO, game theory, could be described as "decision theory from multiple perspectives".

1107042753870000130.text: There's an significant overlap in methods used, mostly deriving from linear (and the various nonlinear) optimization models. Industrial engineering has about 20 years of headstart on methods, largely bc it isn't constrained by linearity considerations.

1107041673606057986.text: So both fields have this habit of seeing their subject, firm or market, as a little sputtering machine that requires constant attention and fine-tuning to run smoothly. Industrial organization evolved specifically from the theory of imperfect competition.

1107040989192044544.text: [For those who find that too soulless, this also includes minimizing the loss of life. A massive impetus to go down the path of driving automation was to put an end to the 1 million casualties from vehicle accidents.]

1107040983890440193.text: The biggest commonality is that both have a very technical view of their core subject, using formal models to describe and improve the overall functioning of it. The overarching goal is to improve efficiency and minimize loss.

1105414948832841728.text: Just a FAQ, since I'm getting a bunch of responses along the lines of "this is just the same as _______ bias": I am trying to establish the ultimate cause (the way we perceive the world) for a number of well-established proximate biases. Ultimate and proximate are not same-same.

1105403347807305728.text: [H/t to @AnniRaasu for motivating this thread by reminiscing about the human-curated days of @ThisIsMyJam]

1105402758243471360.text: So we should not be surprised at all that the machines we're building in our image to do our work are just replicating what we teach them, including our own biases.

1105401646228619264.text: Outside of ML, this bias is even more pervasive (and sinister) in the form of xenophobia, which is the impulse to attribute all negative traits of a member of the outgroup to the outgroup as a whole, while negative traits of an ingroup member are attributed to the member.

1105399972902723584.text: But I distinctly remember even my original Neural Network textbooks, which were written in the 1980s and 90s, discuss this classification problem: Giving the network the autonomy to create a new class only works if the data is reflective of the population it tries to map.

1105398136279887872.text: This bias has gotten a lot of renewed attention recently because ML algorithms, which are essentially tasked to "put alike things together and then create boundaries between what you think are clusters", have gotten this tasks all kinds of wrong.

1105397054656917505.text: Call this the "world music effect", where world music is usually a genre shorthand for "music of all sorts not sung in English or not 'English-sounding'".

1105396491508768769.text: More formally, any type of data-driven classification will run into this problem if the data itself contains this bias, for instance because it was collected within a certain social perimeter.

1105392821484298240.text: It's simply that within a certain visual perimeter, we're able to place all the beach dwellers in their two-dimensional position, while everyone outside the perimeter, to either side, seems bunched up against the one-dimensional backdrop.

1105391153417875458.text:
This goes all the way back to spending summer vacations on the beach, where my sister casually observed one day that our section of the beach always seemed less crowded than all the others.

A little stroll along the beach showed that this seemed to be the case wherever we went.

Help group → respect property (enable formal exchange)
Defer to superiors → divide resources fairly (enable vertical exchange)

Be brave → protect the perimeter or venture out to secure provisions.

1103978154522304512.text:
Where do we go from here?

There's been some geographical mingling of late and a convergence towards the border of Mitte and Kreuzberg (near the famous Checkpoint Charlie), but the mingling of the minds is still waiting to happen. 

Maybe once we all hang out in the same cafés.pic.twitter.com/0A9OunXcvC

1103976759421292544.text:
The western district of Charlottenburg (home of the TU campus) as well as other peripheral locations like Adlershof, Buch, or the nearby city of Potsdam are home to the traditional tech (as opposed to –tech) spinoffs.

With little socializing, and lots of tinkering underground.pic.twitter.com/evGAandbgU

1103973582298931200.text: The caffeine, creativity, counterculture and coworking-rich districts of Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg and Neukölln are home to the dreamers, the revolutionaries, and the digital agencies.pic.twitter.com/quuiUj5pl9

1103971402254831616.text: The central district of Mitte, which in the 1990s provided the creative spark for both the techno and the startup scenes to emerge, is now the epicenter of the "spreadsheet" driven startups.pic.twitter.com/Y8mkC7tZvQ

1103970412235538432.text:
A startup is a combination of a dream, a technology, and a spreadsheet.

The Berlin startup scene can still be neatly divided into those three ingredients, with very little of the mixing and matching we see in Silicon Valley.pic.twitter.com/Hb6Cqqgik4

1103969388175261697.text:
Today, after some 20+ years of internal and external mixing and migrating, Berlin is no longer split into East and West, but Inside or Outside (the Ringbahn). 

Outside, 70% were born in Berliners. Inside, 70% were *not* born in Berlin, including a high % not born in Germany.pic.twitter.com/kJOT3BGXf4

1103968101908074497.text:
To get to the bottom of it, it's useful to look back.

For 40 years Berlin was diaspora to the German economic miracle. The place you would go to to not have a career, a refuge where you could be “anti-establishment”. 

This sentiment lingers 30 years after the Wall came down.pic.twitter.com/UzUfxdRugk

1103965454169714689.text:
Berlin, the capital and biggest city by far, sits in a remote corner surrounded by forests and lakes. It has almost no corporate HQs.

But in the last years all the tech players: Daimler, Telekom, SAP, Porsche, Lufthansa, Bosch came to Berlin to open digital labs & accelerators.pic.twitter.com/47Jq9ZHsg8

1103964218917875713.text:
Innovative capacity in Germany is highly decentralized. The population skews west, tech skews south.

Which raises the question: Why are we here?pic.twitter.com/V4O2j8jpAr

1103963402102325248.text:
The most succinct answer is "No." 

German technological innovation happens in the most unlikely places:
• Neckarsulm, pop. 26,828
• Herzogenaurach, pop. 22,972
• Walldorf, pop. 15,460
• Montabaur, pop. 12,486
etc.pic.twitter.com/G2kqHdFvD1

1093924056854859776.text:
And the only way to fix this hole is to get every single tier to agree to share their production, warehousing, and quality control data with you and ideally among each other.

That's the mutuality problem in supply chain.

1093923559850823680.text:
If you don't have the means to investigate & fix this supply stoppage in time, there is a good chance you'll end up with 50,000 high-priced brand name products you cannot assemble bc there is a $200k-shaped hole in your supply chain inbound.

And 50,000 pissed-off non-customers.

1093922485928714240.text:
Regardless, there is a pretty good chance that the tier 5 supplier should be producing some 50k $4 parts that end up somewhere in your products, but doesn't. Because tier 5 is down.

And the production stoppage will explode through your supply like it does in the MIT beer game.

1093921332331462656.text:
Typically you don't have contractual relationship with any supplier beyond tier 2. Tier 5 might not even know if their parts end up in your product.

And if they have a monopoly on their production process, which is common, they are in a pretty good bargaining position.

1093920428844822529.text:
Tier 5's products end up as components is a few tier 4 suppliers' products, which should appear in tier 4's bill of materials, after which tier 5's part numbers disappear.

Tier 5 is under no obligation to give you production volumes, stock, or customer list. Neither is tier 4.

1093919000239718403.text:
At this point, you, the OEM ("tier 0"), a big brand name, volume manufacturer of a high tech product, have no idea if this small company produces anything that could end up in any of your own products, assembled from some 10,000 components. 

It just could be.

1093918997073063938.text:
Let's create a stylized but very common supply chain disruption example where a "single truth without single source" data architectures come in handy:

A tier 5 type supplier (small specialized manufacturer) goes down and you first hear about it in the trade news.https://twitter.com/adamdavidlong/status/1093914761874403333 …

1093650490208993280.text:
There's a big leap from forming a governance structure and giving it proprietary access to the data flow.

The potential for applying blockchains in supply chain derives from a requirement for mutuality in data sharing. If you create a data monopoly, that goes out the window.

1090543492592558080.text:
With more fine-tuning of this idea I expect startup-based product development to eventually completely supplant corporate R&D.

As it is, corporates are already struggling to implement "startup-like" models in their innovation centers and digital labs.

1090542385581432832.text:
Going back from hunt to search, which is all too common both in startup and corporate R&D, is hugely detrimental. 

If there are clear indicators that a team is going wrong during the hunting phase, it is better to set up a new team to investigate the arising opportunity.

1090541329766068225.text:
The main thing startups need to learn is to foster the two mindsets within the product team and draw a clear line when Search is over and the Hunt begins.

When you spend part of your development phase fine-tuning your "Agile" approach, it means you are too slow and unprepared.

1090540290795077632.text:
Especially tech startups tend to have enormous problems allocating the resources, attention, and skills to the market development counterpart of product development.

The result is usually cool technology but no market.

1090540289255768064.text:
Startups can't afford to have separate R and D teams, so everyone needs to do everything to get a product to market.

Also early-stage startups should not engage in multi-year R or D projects. Verify that your go-to-market approach works first before you stretch out.

1090538287301832704.text:
My main focus was, and to a certain extent still is, corporate R&D, and I would spend ten more years there, most in very early (10-30 years to market) tech research.

In the meantime startups, out of sheer necessity, have gotten much closer to working off such a model.

1090536066086510592.text:
1995 was the birth of the dot-com boom, Illinois was the home of the web browser, and the campus was bustling with startuppy activities all trying to follow in Marc Andreesen's footsteps. 

At that point I had spent all of two weeks yahoo-ing the Internet.

1090534866700156928.text:
Bc the second phase, the hunt, has to work out in perfect sync. There should be no more disagreement on specs or on methods. There should be no more going back to searching. 

Hunting the wrong target or hunting too slowly are both failure points exhausting important resources.

1090532682549874689.text:
I called the two phases "search" and "hunt". Search is a comparatively leisurely activity, the sit idly on knoll and scan the environment phase. 

It is about identifying the right target, and about coming to a mutual understanding as to why it is the right target.
